story.text: This page tries to collect questions asked by people meeting Fedwiki the first time. Maybe they will be answered someday by the people deeply familiar with Fedwiki.
## [[Why "wiki"]]
The word "wiki" in _Federation Wiki_ seems counter-intuitive. The "wiki" concept was originally a way to edit webpages fast, then do it cooperatively in a relatively painless way.
Fediwiki concept seems to be based on **infinite amount of forking**, **information divergence** and **hiding information needles in fork haystacks**.

> What happens when there is a page, then 50 people [want to] fix 50 punctuation errors on it? In the end will there be 51 divergent and disconnected versions scattered everywhere, most of them with only a few changes of the total? And worse: invisible to everyone but the persons made the edit. And the original left unfixed.
Fediwiki does not seem to support collaborative documents, it seems to support infinite amount of branched information and haphazard (and manual) information merges.

Maybe it is because the picking of the word "wiki" wasn't quite that a good idea. It has stuck to [[Ward Cunningham]] as stray dog fed with smoked ham but the meaning is already out in the wild and cannot be changed at will.
Also remember [[Knol]] (The Wikipedia Killerâ„¢ from Google), and how it have failed the seemingly similar idea.
### The example of the Infinite Forks

Take an imagined _GitHub_ project, which has been around for years, and popular. It has been forked 15000 times. Github can't even show its network graph, so ther seem to be no way to know which fork is active, which is dead, which have been merged back, or which collected changes from other forks. And which is dead. You can click them all, and check manually. If you dare.

I also did backmerging a few times: forking the most active fork then merging **manually** all useful changes from other forks. Took **weeks** of manual labour. And lot of searching. And it was just about a doen forks.
## [[Comparing Versions]]

Fedwiki keeps history, probably full history, and gives a [[Journal]] to show the events. But there seem to be no way to show the __actual changes__, comparing versions. I admittedly live and breath on change-diffs in [[Wikipedia]].
It seems it's also invisible __who__ have made the changes.
## "Forking"
It seems to be common knowledge among fediwikians that when you want to, well, not collaborate, but get involved in a nonspecific way in a page, then you should fork it.
It is not deadly obvious, though. Okay, you need to have your own (editable) fediwiki, either on a farm or at your place, but then, how to pull the page into your wiki? You cannot just _go there_....
I believe the plan is to somehow find neighbours, maybe searching, or following obscure links? Then you can try to link pages existing at the neighbours, _then_ you can fork them. I believe?

story.caption: Uploaded image
story.text: Uploaded image

See this image! (If you do see it, and if it's there.) I hav forked a page from _mud.ward_ (the rightmost window is from _mudward_ origin). Then edited. And _mudward_ showed at the top that there is a newer fork of the page. Half a day have passed. Now while my page knows it's been forked from _mudward_, the latter is oblivious, like nobody have ever forked it.

The green numbers are the creation order. Can you tell by looking at the image? Could you tell which is newer, more fresh, or which was created by someone you trust and which by a spammer selling you fake viagra on fake phishing sites?
## Instability of reach

I had a working link yesterday ([[Ideas to Impact]]). Probably, back then the site where the page exists wa sin my neighbourhood list. Today (in a new session) it might not. So the link results a __ghost__ page: "We could not find this page".
## Community

It is not obvious whether one editing (which is not editing, but anyway) (as I do now) is a member of a community or not? And if so (and it seems that way) are there any expected behaviours from you? Any guidelines to follow? Or just feel your inner chaos?
## Split horizon
The constant forks and branches result pages eerily similar yet different, or chains of pages where most of the pages are looking the same but there may be subtle differences.

The common observer may not even be aware that they is seeing __A__ while others have seen __B__ and they talk about it like it was the same and both believe they seen the same. Except when the differences come up, and both may think the other is mad, while only their realities became disjunct.
## Consumer vs. creator

When I have started creating ISPs back in the late 90s I had a problem: people were __users__ of the content, __consumers__, and not __creators__. We have started an assotiation to promote content creation, to promote interactivity since we have realised (and I have been known all along) that a world full of creators is a great place while the world where content is provided by a chosen few centralised institiution is a really bad one. And, uh, we're in the age when I shall be really satisfied to see that I've been right all along.

Now, it seemed to me, reading through the introductory pages of fedwiki that the target audience is still customers and not creators. Felt bad. The opposite what I've felt when met Ward's Wiki the first time. Maybe I just not yet see The Light.
## Images
Fediwiki seems to be right in compressing uploaded images to save space. However it seems to be oblivious about the fact that JPEG may not be the best choice for extreme compression.

I'd like to suggest to consider __webp__ format, which compresses way better looking results to significantly smaller size. It is supported by major browsers and there are available compatibility layers for the rest. (Funnily my inserted _webp_ image was expanded double size, its quality was quartered since it was converted to jpeg.)

Also it seems I simply cannot _insert_ images. There is no "image" plugin, and the default paragraph __needs__ drag and drop. I don't quite remember when have I used "drag and drop", but probably not the last 2 decades. Nor does it easily work: it doesn't accept a lot of "drop" types, I have to actually save the image, open it in some graphical browser, then drag from there. Four-five additional steps. (This is an UI question, I know.)
## [[What About Abuse?]]

What about copyrighted material? Porn? Nazis? All the trash on the internet we see on multiple networks? Obviously anyone can create a nazi fediwiki, but how can others dissociate themselves? Can they? Is the service spammable? Reverse spam, reference spam, forkspam?
# [[How to Make A Mark?]]

eric: if I stand on my origin, how am I supposed to make any sign on your fork, or yours on mine? [https://matrix.to/#/!ORfrUEFeWFcHAMLFLr:matrix.org/$1643992243178MViUt:grin.hu?via=matrix.org&via=matrix.allmende.io&via=diglife.coop chat]
## See also
* [[The Problem Collector]] (for unsorted experience notes)
